title: We received APPROVED Loan Modification papers from our lender, Notarized & returned. Now they don't acknowledge sending them?
question: In the past 4-5 years, I have twice lost my job. During those times, we applied for Loan Modification and Hardship help with my lender. The first unemployment (once I got another job), they said no to Loan modification and just added the missed payments to the end of my loan. This last time (last year) gave us a 6 month hardship forbearance. After that time period (and my new employment), we received ( Fed Ex) a letter and docs saying WE WERE APPROVED for a Loan Modification. We returned in Fed Ex supplied by lender. A few days before we received these Loan Docs, I was contemplating Bankruptcy (Chapter 7 -House NOT included). Once we received the Loan Mod, I knew I could afford house w Chapter 7. So filed. Lender acts now like APPROVED Loan Mod never sent. Want to foreclose. Help?
answers:
Your situation changed when you filed C7 BK.
Common for lenders in this arena to "lose" documents. Lender may not be communicating with you out of fear of violation BK automatic stay.. All debts, including this one, must be included in C7 BK filing. You may be able to retain the house, keep the loan in place, protect equity in C7.
Need more information to opine further. Consult BK counsel.to review all options.

Chapter 7 throws out your loan modification. There are serious ramifications to reaffirming a loan modification, banks usually don't understand the issues of loan modification. However, it all depends on what you signed whether it is a good idea to renegotiate a new loan modification or get a totally new one. This is a rather common issue and you need to discuss this with your attorney. The debt is listed what to do with it is the question and I have experience on the creditors side and the bankruptcy side so I am much more experienced than you average Debtors attorney.

The banks theoretically could say if you just reaffirm or agree to the former loan modification that you technically reaffirmed or agreed to liability of the debt. Although they have yet to do that from my experience and practice it is possible. I view it malpractice in my state to reaffirm a mortgage in my state as reaffirmation agreements are not required for a foreclosure to take place there must be a default. Other states such as California may be different. Talk to your lawyer and have them review the loan modification! See what they think you should do with regards to the debt which is significant!

If you filed pro se, you may have filed your chapter 7 case and not listed the mortgage thinking that not listing the debt means that it is not included in the bankruptcy case. If that is what happened, that was a big mistake, Almost 100% of national lenders and a significant number of local lenders pay for a service from one of the three credit bureaus or some other company related to bankruptcy filings. What they receive for that fee is a download of a list of everyone in the U.S. that has filed a petition for relief under the bankruptcy code in the past week. Then the lender's computer compares the download to all of the borrowers that currently have loans with that lender.

If you want help, then you need to take the time to meet with an experienced bankruptcy attorney that handles chapter 7 and chapter 13 cases. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you at no charge for the initial appointment. You can use the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page to search for an attorney.

It is not possible to file a proper BK and omit the largest debt you have (your home mortgage). If you are not using an attorney to help with your BK, big mistake. Find/consult/hire an Avvo lawyer by clicking the tab "Find a Lawyer". Many of us offer a free consultation.

Your home loan IS included - there is no choice. You did a loan modification, and then asked for a discharge of that debt in Chapter 7. The lender is reacting. Certainly you were told that before filing?

Your whole scenario changed when you said you filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy. Did you hire an attorney to represent you in your Ch. 7 BK? If not, you should. It's not too late. Your bankruptcy attorney will be able to help you with this loan modification. Email or call a bankruptcy attorney to get a full consultation.
